scenario.text: An unusually warm spring in southeastern Europe creates a surplus in foreign wheat imports.
Summer flooding across the Midwestern states decreases soybean crop production.
Health concerns about foreign meat in Australia decrease livestock exports from other regions.
Economic growth in China creates an increased demand for North American beef products.
Russia lifts restrictions on wheat exports, greatly increasing global trade supplies.
Decreased grain production in Asia increases competition among foreign exporters.
News of cattle infections hits the media, and the demand for beef hits an all-time low.
A bacterial infection spreads among Oklahoma cattle, thinning out livestock supply for months.
The U.S. dollar is strong, inviting global merchants to capitalize on healthy market conditions.
Economic woes in Europe slow down the commodity markets as the euro hits an all-time low.
Rail expansions make it more efficient and cost-effective to transport domestic commodities.
High oil prices make it more expensive to transport food to and from foreign markets.
Recent shifts in biofuel policies allow U.S. corn farmers to devote more land to food production.
Expansion of grain production places a premium on suitable farmland for coffee plantations.
Peacekeeping efforts in the Middle East lighten restrictions on agricultural exports to Western nations.
Political volatility in Egypt halts wheat exports altogether, causing price spikes around the world.
